skill.name: solid-principles
skill.description: SOLID design principles for .NET. Use when designing classes, interfaces, and object relationships. Ensures maintainable, testable, and extensible code.
skill.summary: SOLID design principles for .NET. Use when designing classes, interfaces, and object relationships. ...
skill.author: DoubleslashSE

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and code examples for SOLID design principles. No executable code, network calls, file system access, or environment variable access detected. Pure educational content with C# examples.

content.value_statement: Design patterns create maintainable software. SOLID principles guide you to build testable, extensible .NET applications that scale with business needs.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes C# code for SOLID principle violations
Suggests refactoring patterns for each SOLID principle
Provides before/after code examples with explanations
limitations: Requires existing code to analyze patterns

use_cases.title: Learn SOLID fundamentals
use_cases.description: Understand each principle through practical C# examples and common violations

use_cases.title: Review architecture decisions
use_cases.description: Validate design choices and identify refactoring opportunities in legacy code

use_cases.title: Establish coding standards
use_cases.description: Create team guidelines and review checklists based on SOLID principles

prompt_templates.title: Identify SOLID violations
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this C# class and identify which SOLID principles it violates. For each violation, explain why and suggest a refactoring approach.

prompt_templates.title: Apply Single Responsibility
prompt_templates.prompt: Refactor this class to follow Single Responsibility Principle. Extract separate classes for each responsibility and show the improved design.

prompt_templates.title: Design extensible systems
prompt_templates.prompt: Redesign this switch statement to follow Open/Closed Principle using strategy pattern or polymorphism.

prompt_templates.title: Implement dependency inversion
prompt_templates.prompt: Refactor this service to depend on abstractions instead of concrete implementations. Show the interface design and dependency injection setup.

output_examples.input: My OrderService class handles validation, business logic, database access, and email notifications. How can I improve it?
output: Single Responsibility Violation: OrderService has 4 responsibilities
Extract validation logic into OrderValidator class
Extract database operations into OrderRepository class
Inject dependencies through constructor for testability

best_practices: Start with Single Responsibility - split classes by reason to change
Use dependency injection to invert dependencies and improve testability
Design interfaces that are specific to client needs
anti_patterns: God classes that handle multiple business domains
Deep inheritance hierarchies with overridden behavior

faq.question: Which SOLID principle should I learn first?
faq.answer: Start with Single Responsibility Principle. It provides the foundation for clean code and makes other principles easier to apply.

faq.question: Can I apply SOLID principles to existing code?
faq.answer: Yes. Start by identifying violations in critical classes and refactor incrementally. Focus on areas with frequent changes first.

faq.question: Does SOLID apply only to object-oriented languages?
faq.answer: While designed for OOP, SOLID concepts apply to any paradigm. The principles focus on maintainability and extensibility.

faq.question: How do I know if I'm over-engineering with SOLID?
faq.answer: Apply YAGNI principle. Use SOLID when you have actual requirements for flexibility, not hypothetical future needs.

faq.question: What's the relationship between SOLID and design patterns?
faq.answer: SOLID principles guide design decisions. Patterns like Strategy, Factory, and Repository help implement these principles.

faq.question: Are there tools to automatically detect SOLID violations?
faq.answer: Static analysis tools like NDepend, SonarQube, and ReSharper can identify some violations, but manual review is essential.
